philjs-core

View source

The core reactivity system and component primitives for PhilJS.

Functions

Creates a reactive signal with a getter and setter.

function createSignal<T>(initialValue: T, options?: SignalOptions<T>): [Accessor<T>, Setter<T>]

Parameters

initialValueTThe initial value of the signal
options?SignalOptions<T>Optional configuration for the signal

Returns

[Accessor<T>, Setter<T>]A tuple with getter and setter functions

Example

1const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
2 
3console.log(count()); // 0
4setCount(5);
5console.log(count()); // 5
6 
7// With updater function
8setCount(prev => prev + 1);
9console.log(count()); // 6
10 
11// With options
12const [value, setValue] = createSignal(
13  { x: 0, y: 0 },
14  { equals: (a, b) => a.x === b.x && a.y === b.y }
15);

Creates a side effect that automatically tracks and re-runs when dependencies change.

function createEffect<T>(fn: (prev?: T) => T, value?: T): void

Parameters

fn(prev?: T) => TThe effect function to run
value?TOptional initial value passed to the effect

Example

1const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
2 
3createEffect(() => {
4  console.log('Count changed:', count());
5});
6 
7setCount(1); // Logs: "Count changed: 1"
8 
9// With previous value
10createEffect((prev = 0) => {
11  const current = count();
12  console.log(`Changed from ${prev} to ${current}`);
13  return current;
14});

Creates a memoized computed value that only recalculates when dependencies change.

function createMemo<T>(fn: (prev?: T) => T, value?: T, options?: MemoOptions<T>): Accessor<T>

Parameters

fn(prev?: T) => TThe computation function
value?TOptional initial value
options?MemoOptions<T>Optional configuration

Returns

Accessor<T>A getter function that returns the memoized value

Example

1const [firstName, setFirstName] = createSignal('John');
2const [lastName, setLastName] = createSignal('Doe');
3 
4const fullName = createMemo(() => {
5  console.log('Computing...');
6  return `${firstName()} ${lastName()}`;
7});
8 
9console.log(fullName()); // "Computing...", "John Doe"
10console.log(fullName()); // "John Doe" (cached)
11 
12setFirstName('Jane');
13console.log(fullName()); // "Computing...", "Jane Doe"

Creates a resource for async data fetching with loading and error states.

function createResource<T, S>(source: Accessor<S> | false | null | undefined, fetcher: (source: S, info: ResourceFetcherInfo) => T | Promise<T>): ResourceReturn<T>

Parameters

sourceAccessor<S>Source signal that triggers refetching when it changes
fetcher(source: S) => T | Promise<T>Async function that fetches the data

Returns

ResourceReturn<T>Resource accessor and control methods

Example

1const [userId, setUserId] = createSignal(1);
2 
3const [user, { refetch, mutate }] = createResource(
4  userId,
5  async (id) => {
6    const res = await fetch(`/api/users/${id}`);
7    return res.json();
8  }
9);
10 
11// Access data
12user(); // User | undefined
13user.loading; // boolean
14user.error; // Error | null
15user.state; // 'pending' | 'ready' | 'refreshing' | 'errored'
16 
17// Refetch
18refetch();
19 
20// Optimistic update
21mutate(newUserData);

Creates a reactive store for nested state with fine-grained updates.

function createStore<T extends object>(initial: T): [Store<T>, SetStoreFunction<T>]

Parameters

initialTThe initial state object

Returns

[Store<T>, SetStoreFunction<T>]Store accessor and setter function

Example

1const [state, setState] = createStore({
2  user: {
3    name: 'Alice',
4    age: 30,
5  },
6  todos: [
7    { id: 1, text: 'Learn PhilJS', done: false },
8  ],
9});
10 
11// Read
12console.log(state.user.name); // 'Alice'
13 
14// Update nested
15setState('user', 'age', 31);
16 
17// Update with function
18setState('user', 'age', age => age + 1);
19 
20// Array operations
21setState('todos', 0, 'done', true);

Runs a function once when the component is first created and inserted into the DOM.

function onMount(fn: () => void): void

Parameters

fn() => voidThe function to run on mount

Example

1function Component() {
2  onMount(() => {
3    console.log('Component mounted!');
4    fetchData();
5  });
6 
7  return <div>Hello</div>;
8}

Registers a cleanup function to run when the current scope is disposed.

function onCleanup(fn: () => void): void

Parameters

fn() => voidThe cleanup function

Example

1function Timer() {
2  const [time, setTime] = createSignal(0);
3 
4  onMount(() => {
5    const interval = setInterval(() => {
6      setTime(t => t + 1);
7    }, 1000);
8 
9    onCleanup(() => clearInterval(interval));
10  });
11 
12  return <div>{time()}s</div>;
13}

Batches multiple signal updates to prevent unnecessary re-computations.

function batch<T>(fn: () => T): T

Parameters

fn() => TFunction containing the batched updates

Returns

TThe return value of the function

Example

1const [first, setFirst] = createSignal('John');
2const [last, setLast] = createSignal('Doe');
3 
4createEffect(() => {
5  console.log(`${first()} ${last()}`);
6});
7 
8// Without batch: logs twice
9setFirst('Jane');
10setLast('Smith');
11 
12// With batch: logs once
13batch(() => {
14  setFirst('Alice');
15  setLast('Johnson');
16});

Reads signals without creating dependencies in the current tracking scope.

function untrack<T>(fn: () => T): T

Parameters

fn() => TFunction to run without tracking

Returns

TThe return value of the function

Example

1const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
2const [name, setName] = createSignal('Alice');
3 
4createEffect(() => {
5  console.log('Count:', count());
6  console.log('Name:', untrack(name)); // Won't track
7});
8 
9setCount(1); // Logs
10setName('Bob'); // Doesn't log

Creates a context object for passing data through the component tree.

function createContext<T>(defaultValue?: T): Context<T>

Parameters

defaultValue?TOptional default value

Returns

Context<T>Context object

Example

1const ThemeContext = createContext<'light' | 'dark'>('light');
2 
3function App() {
4  const [theme, setTheme] = createSignal<'light' | 'dark'>('dark');
5 
6  return (
7    <ThemeContext.Provider value={theme()}>
8      <Child />
9    </ThemeContext.Provider>
10  );
11}
12 
13function Child() {
14  const theme = useContext(ThemeContext);
15  return <div className={theme}>Content</div>;
16}

Retrieves the value from a context.

function useContext<T>(context: Context<T>): T

Parameters

contextContext<T>The context object

Returns

TThe context value

Example

1const MyContext = createContext<string>();
2 
3function Child() {
4  const value = useContext(MyContext);
5  return <div>{value}</div>;
6}

Lazy loads a component for code splitting.

function lazy<T extends Component<any>>(fn: () => Promise<{ default: T }>): T

Parameters

fn() => Promise<{ default: T }>Function that returns a dynamic import

Returns

TThe lazy-loaded component

Example

1const HeavyComponent = lazy(() => import('./HeavyComponent'));
2 
3function App() {
4  return (
5    <Suspense fallback={<Spinner />}>
6      <HeavyComponent />
7    </Suspense>
8  );
9}

Types

A function that returns the current value of a signal or memo.

Example

1type Accessor<T> = () => T;
2 
3const count: Accessor<number> = createSignal(0)[0];
4console.log(count()); // 0

A function that sets a new value for a signal.

Example

1type Setter<T> = (value: T | ((prev: T) => T)) => T;
2 
3const setCount: Setter<number> = createSignal(0)[1];
4setCount(5);
5setCount(prev => prev + 1);

Options for configuring signal behavior.

Properties

PropertyTypeDescription
equals?(prev: T, next: T) => booleanCustom equality function(default: Object.is)
name?stringDebug name for the signal

Return type of createResource with data accessor and control methods.

Properties

PropertyTypeDescription
loadingbooleanWhether the resource is currently loading
errorError | nullError if the fetch failed
state'pending' | 'ready' | 'refreshing' | 'errored'Current state of the resource
